context: / T +Ln ( T ) − 16.173 where P = absolute pressure of vacuum, kPa; and T = digestate temperature, °C.Effects of boiling point temperature and vacuum on stripping of ammonia As shown in Fig. 4 and Fig. A1, total ammonia concentration in feed decreased steadily after approximately 1 h of temperature ramping and had only 0.1–6.7% remaining upon 3 h (excluding the period of temperature ramping) of vacuum thermal stripping of dairy manure digestate. The fractions of total ammonia remaining at the beginning of vacuum thermal stripping (or the end of temperature ramping) were similar across the 7 boiling conditions (p = 0.66). However, the fractions were significantly higher at stripping temperatures of 50 and 58 °C than those at 65–100 °C after 1.5 h of stripping (p = 0.01; LSD = 0.10) and 3 h of stripping (p = 0.001; LSD = 0.03), which suggested slower stripping of ammonia at 50–58 °C than 65–100 °C. Similarly, the ammonia mass transfer coefficients (K L ) were significantly smaller at 50–58 °C than those at 65–100 °C (p = 0.008; LSD = 9.0) as given in Table 1 . The suction effect of vacuum would enhance gas-phase ammonia mass transfer, but it may not improve overall mass transfer any more as vacuum pressure decreases further below 25.1 kPa. This coincides with earlier studies that ammonia mass transfer coefficient is much more sensitive to a change of air velocity in a lower velocity range than that in a higher velocity range (Ye et al., 2008; Arogo et al., 1999).
